what: Plot a Confusion Matrix Heatmap — plot_conf_matrix
title: Plot a Confusion Matrix Heatmap — plot_conf_matrix
text: function takes confusion matrix object (e.g., caret::confusionMatrix) similar structure containing table predictions versus actuals, generates visually appealing heatmap using ggplot2. displays counts cell uses percentages fill intensity.

title: Plot a Confusion Matrix Heatmap — plot_conf_matrix
code: plot_conf_matrix(   conf_mat,   title = "Confusion Matrix",   palette = "YlOrRd",   class_one = "Class1",   class_two = "Class2" )

title: Plot a Confusion Matrix Heatmap — plot_conf_matrix
text: conf_mat list-like object. object expected element named "table". conf_mat$table table object matrix (convertible tibble) as_tibble(conf_mat$table) results columns predicted values, actual values, column counts (typically named 'n' conf_mat$table table object). function assumes classes "nondiabetic" "diabetic". title character string title plot. Default "Confusion Matrix". palette character string specifying color palette use heatmap. Default "YlOrRd". Additional palettes avaliable via RColorBrewer::display.brewer.(type = "seq"). class_one character string first class label. Default "Class1". class_two character string second class label. Default "Class2".

title: Plot a Confusion Matrix Heatmap — plot_conf_matrix
text: ggplot object representing confusion matrix heatmap.

title: Plot a Confusion Matrix Heatmap — plot_conf_matrix
code: # Ensure modeldata and yardstick are available for the example if (rlang::is_installed("modeldata") && rlang::is_installed("yardstick")) {   data("two_class_example", package = "modeldata")   cm <-     yardstick::conf_mat(       two_class_example,       truth = truth, # 'truth' is a column name in two_class_example       estimate = predicted # 'predicted' is a column name in two_class_example     )   plot_conf_matrix(cm,                    title = "Sample Confusion Matrix",                    palette = "Blues",                    class_one = "Class1", # Matches levels in two_class_example                    class_two = "Class2"  # Matches levels in two_class_example                   ) }
